articles.title: Â¿Es DifÃ­cil Aprender Sueco? Una EvaluaciÃ³n Honesta
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';

# Â¿Es DifÃ­cil Aprender Sueco? Una EvaluaciÃ³n Honesta para Hispanohablantes

Si estÃ¡s considerando aprender sueco para tu pareja, probablemente te preguntas: Â¿quÃ© tan difÃ­cil es realmente? Para los hispanohablantes, el sueco presenta algunos desafÃ­os Ãºnicos, pero tambiÃ©n tiene caracterÃ­sticas que lo hacen mÃ¡s accesible de lo que podrÃ­as pensar.

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Det gÃ¥r bra"
  translation="Va bien / EstÃ¡ bien"
  pronunciation="deh gawr brah"
  context="Una frase Ãºtil que aprenderÃ¡s rÃ¡pidamenteâ€”Â¡y esperemos que uses a menudo al describir tus estudios de sueco!"
/>

## Las Buenas Noticias: Por QuÃ© el Sueco Es MÃ¡s FÃ¡cil de lo Que Piensas

### 1. GramÃ¡tica Simplificada

Comparado con el espaÃ±ol, la gramÃ¡tica sueca es mucho mÃ¡s simple en varios aspectos:

| Aspecto | EspaÃ±ol | Sueco |
|---------|---------|-------|
| **ConjugaciÃ³n verbal** | 6 formas por tiempo | 1 forma para todos |
| **GÃ©nero gramatical** | 2 gÃ©neros + concordancia | 2 gÃ©neros, sin concordancia con adjetivos |
| **Casos gramaticales** | Vestigiales | No existen |
| **Subjuntivo** | Extenso y complejo | PrÃ¡cticamente inexistente |

<VocabCard
  word="Jag pratar"
  translation="Yo hablo"
  pronunciation="yah PRAH-tar"
  example="Jag pratar svenska. (Yo hablo sueco.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Du pratar"
  translation="TÃº hablas"
  pronunciation="doo PRAH-tar"
  example="Du pratar svenska bra! (Â¡TÃº hablas sueco bien!)"
/>

Â¿Notas cÃ³mo el verbo "pratar" no cambia? Â¡Eso es un gran alivio comparado con el espaÃ±ol!

### 2. Vocabulario Internacional

El sueco ha adoptado muchas palabras internacionales:

| Sueco | EspaÃ±ol | Notas |
|-------|---------|-------|
| **Telefon** | TelÃ©fono | Casi idÃ©ntico |
| **Restaurang** | Restaurante | Muy similar |
| **Musik** | MÃºsica | Reconocible |
| **Familj** | Familia | Mismo origen |
| **Problem** | Problema | IdÃ©ntico |

<CultureTip title="Dificultad SegÃºn el FSI" flag="ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡ª">
El Instituto del Servicio Exterior de EE.UU. clasifica el sueco como un idioma de CategorÃ­a I, el mÃ¡s fÃ¡cil para angloparlantes. Para hispanohablantes, el sueco estÃ¡ en un nivel intermedio de dificultadâ€”mÃ¡s fÃ¡cil que el chino o Ã¡rabe, pero con sus propios desafÃ­os Ãºnicos.
</CultureTip>

### 3. Los Suecos Hablan Excelente InglÃ©s (y a Menudo EspaÃ±ol)

Esto es Ãºtil para principiantes. Puedes hacer preguntas, aclarar significados y obtener retroalimentaciÃ³n instantÃ¡nea de tu pareja o amigos suecos.

## Los DesafÃ­os: Lo Que Hace al Sueco Complicado

### 1. La PronunciaciÃ³n Requiere PrÃ¡ctica

El sueco tiene sonidos que no existen en espaÃ±ol:

<VocabCard
  word="Sju"
  translation="Siete"
  pronunciation="hwoo (con la parte trasera de la lengua)"
  example="Det Ã¤r sju kronor."
/>

El sonido "sj" sueco es notoriamente difÃ­cil. Es un sonido sibilante hecho en la parte posterior de la garganta. Â¡No te preocupesâ€”incluso los niÃ±os suecos tardan tiempo en dominarlo!

### 2. El Acento Tonal

El sueco es un idioma tonal (mÃ¡s o menos). Las palabras pueden tener diferentes significados segÃºn su patrÃ³n de entonaciÃ³n:

| Palabra | Significado Tono 1 | Significado Tono 2 |
|---------|-------------------|-------------------|
| **Anden** | El pato | El espÃ­ritu |
| **Tomten** | El terreno | Santa Claus |

Â¡No te asustes! El contexto casi siempre aclara el significado, y los suecos te entenderÃ¡n aunque tu tono no sea perfecto.

### 3. En vs. Ett

Los sustantivos suecos son palabras "en" o palabras "ett", y no hay una regla infalible para saber cuÃ¡l es cuÃ¡l. NecesitarÃ¡s memorizar el gÃ©nero de cada sustantivo:

<VocabCard
  word="En bok"
  translation="Un libro (gÃ©nero comÃºn)"
  pronunciation="en book"
  example="Det Ã¤r en bra bok."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ett hus"
  translation="Una casa (gÃ©nero neutro)"
  pronunciation="ett hoos"
  example="Vi har ett stort hus."
/>

### 4. Reglas de Orden de Palabras

El sueco tiene una regla "V2"â€”el verbo debe ser el segundo elemento en una oraciÃ³n:

| EspaÃ±ol | Sueco | Notas |
|---------|-------|-------|
| Hoy trabajo yo | **Idag jobbar jag** | El verbo va segundo |
| Yo trabajo hoy | **Jag jobbar idag** | Orden estÃ¡ndar |

<CultureTip title="La Regla V2" flag="ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡ª">
Esta regla V2 significa que cuando comienzas una oraciÃ³n con algo que no sea el sujeto (como una palabra de tiempo), el sujeto y el verbo se invierten. Se siente extraÃ±o al principio pero se vuelve automÃ¡tico con la prÃ¡ctica.
</CultureTip>

## Hablemos en Serio: Â¿CuÃ¡nto Tiempo TomarÃ¡?

Para estudiantes dedicados que estudian algunas horas semanales con una pareja sueca:

| Objetivo | Tiempo Estimado |
|----------|-----------------|
| Conversaciones bÃ¡sicas | 4-8 meses |
| Sueco cotidiano cÃ³modo | 8-14 meses |
| Leer noticias/libros fÃ¡cilmente | 1.5-2.5 aÃ±os |
| ComunicaciÃ³n casi fluida | 2.5-4 aÃ±os |

Â¡Estos plazos asumen prÃ¡ctica regular e inmersiÃ³n a travÃ©s de tu relaciÃ³n!

## Consejos para Hacer el Sueco MÃ¡s FÃ¡cil

1. **Aprovecha los cognados** - Busca similitudes con palabras internacionales
2. **Aprende "en/ett" con cada sustantivo** - Di "en bok" no solo "bok"
3. **No temas al tono** - VendrÃ¡ naturalmente con el tiempo
4. **Practica escuchando** - Las series de TV suecas ayudan con la pronunciaciÃ³n
5. **Â¡Habla desde el dÃ­a uno!** - Tu pareja es tu mejor maestro/a

## El Veredicto

Â¿Es difÃ­cil aprender sueco? **Tiene sus desafÃ­os, especialmente la pronunciaciÃ³n y el sistema tonal, pero la gramÃ¡tica simplificada lo hace muy alcanzable.** Con una pareja sueca con quien practicar, tienes una ventaja que muchos estudiantes de idiomas sueÃ±an.

<VocabCard
  word="Du klarar det!"
  translation="Â¡TÃº puedes! / Â¡Lo lograrÃ¡s!"
  pronunciation="doo KLAH-rar deh"
  example="El sueco no es fÃ¡cil, pero du klarar det!"
/>

<CTA />

articles.title: 50 Ukrainian Compliments for Your Partner
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Ukrainian is a beautifully expressive language, and when it comes to complimenting loved ones, it offers an incredibly rich vocabulary. Learning to compliment your partner in Ukrainian will show them how much you care and appreciate them.

## The Most Beautiful Compliment

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ¿Ñ€ĞµĞºÑ€Ğ°ÑĞ½Ğ°"
  translation="You are gorgeous (to a woman)"
  pronunciation="Ty prek-RAS-na"
  context="One of the most heartfelt compliments in Ukrainian. 'ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞºÑ€Ğ°ÑĞ½Ğ°' conveys exceptional, breathtaking beauty."
/>

In Ukrainian culture, sincere compliments carry real meaning. They're not given casually, so when you compliment someone, it truly touches their heart.

## Complimenting Appearance

### For Women

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ ĞºÑ€Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ²Ğ°"
  translation="You are beautiful"
  pronunciation="Ty kra-SY-va"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ° ĞºÑ€Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ²Ğ° ÑÑŒĞ¾Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ñ–!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ‡Ğ°Ñ€Ñ–Ğ²Ğ½Ğ°"
  translation="You are charming/enchanting"
  pronunciation="Ty cha-RIV-na"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ° Ñ‡Ğ°Ñ€Ñ–Ğ²Ğ½Ğ°!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ½ĞµĞ¿Ğ¾Ğ²Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ½Ğ°"
  translation="You are unique"
  pronunciation="Ty ne-pov-TOR-na"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ½ĞµĞ¿Ğ¾Ğ²Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ½Ğ°, ĞºĞ¾Ñ…Ğ°Ğ½Ğ°."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ‡ÑƒĞ´Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°"
  translation="You are wonderful"
  pronunciation="Ty chu-DO-va"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ Ñ‡ÑƒĞ´Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ·ĞºÑ–ÑˆĞ½Ğ°"
  translation="You are gorgeous/luxurious"
  pronunciation="Ty roz-KISH-na"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ»ÑĞ´Ğ°Ñ”Ñˆ Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ·ĞºÑ–ÑˆĞ½Ğ¾!"
/>

### For Men

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ ĞºÑ€Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ¹"
  translation="You are handsome"
  pronunciation="Ty kra-SY-vy"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ ĞºÑ€Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ¹!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ°Ğ±Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ¹"
  translation="You are attractive"
  pronunciation="Ty pry-vab-LY-vy"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ´ÑƒĞ¶Ğµ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ°Ğ±Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ñ‡Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ²Ñ–Ğº."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ¼ÑƒĞ¶Ğ½Ñ–Ğ¹"
  translation="You are manly/courageous"
  pronunciation="Ty muzh-NIY"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¼ÑƒĞ¶Ğ½Ñ–Ğ¹!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ³Ğ°Ğ½Ñ‚Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¹"
  translation="You are elegant"
  pronunciation="Ty e-le-GANT-ny"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ³Ğ°Ğ½Ñ‚Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¹ ÑÑŒĞ¾Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ñ–!"
/>

<CultureTip title="Gender Agreement" flag="ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦">
Ukrainian adjectives change based on the gender of the person you're addressing. Words ending in "-Ğ¸Ğ¹" are masculine, while "-Ğ°" or "-Ğ½Ğ°" endings are feminine. Using the correct form shows respect for the language and your partner!
</CultureTip>

## Complimenting Specific Features

### Eyes

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ£ Ñ‚ĞµĞ±Ğµ ĞºÑ€Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ²Ñ– Ğ¾Ñ‡Ñ–"
  translation="You have beautiful eyes"
  pronunciation="U TE-be kra-SY-vi O-chi"
  example="Ğ£ Ñ‚ĞµĞ±Ğµ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºÑ– ĞºÑ€Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ²Ñ– Ğ¾Ñ‡Ñ–!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¯ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ½Ñƒ Ğ² Ñ‚Ğ²Ğ¾Ñ—Ñ… Ğ¾Ñ‡Ğ°Ñ…"
  translation="I'm drowning in your eyes"
  pronunciation="Ya TO-nu v tvo-YIKH o-CHAKH"
  example="A deeply romantic expression."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ²Ğ¾Ñ— Ğ¾Ñ‡Ñ– ÑĞº Ğ·Ğ¾Ñ€Ñ–"
  translation="Your eyes are like stars"
  pronunciation="Tvo-YI O-chi yak ZO-ri"
  example="Romantic and poetic!"
/>

### Smile

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ£ Ñ‚ĞµĞ±Ğµ Ñ‡ÑƒĞ´Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑĞ¼Ñ–ÑˆĞºĞ°"
  translation="You have a wonderful smile"
  pronunciation="U TE-be chu-DO-va pos-MISH-ka"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ²Ğ¾Ñ Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑĞ¼Ñ–ÑˆĞºĞ° Ğ¾ÑĞ²Ñ–Ñ‚Ğ»ÑÑ” ĞºÑ–Ğ¼Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‚Ñƒ."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ¿Ñ€ĞµĞºÑ€Ğ°ÑĞ½Ğ°, ĞºĞ¾Ğ»Ğ¸ ÑƒÑĞ¼Ñ–Ñ…Ğ°Ñ”ÑˆÑÑ"
  translation="You're beautiful when you smile"
  pronunciation="Ty prek-RAS-na, ko-LY us-mi-KHA-yesh-sya"
  example="For a woman."
/>

### Voice

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ£ Ñ‚ĞµĞ±Ğµ Ğ³Ğ°Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ñ"
  translation="You have a beautiful voice"
  pronunciation="U TE-be GAR-ny HO-los"
  example="ĞœĞµĞ½Ñ– Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ°Ñ”Ñ‚ÑŒÑÑ ÑĞ»ÑƒÑ…Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ²Ñ–Ğ¹ Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ñ."
/>

## Personality Compliments

### Kindness and Character

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¹/Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ°"
  translation="You are kind (m/f)"
  pronunciation="Ty DOB-ry / DOB-ra"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ° Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ° Ğ´Ğ¾ Ğ²ÑÑ–Ñ…."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ‚ÑƒÑ€Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ¹/Ñ‚ÑƒÑ€Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ°"
  translation="You are caring (m/f)"
  pronunciation="Ty tur-bot-LY-vy / tur-bot-LY-va"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ Ñ‚ÑƒÑ€Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¿Ğ°Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ½ĞµÑ€."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ‡ÑƒĞ¹Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¹/Ñ‡ÑƒĞ¹Ğ½Ğ°"
  translation="You are sensitive/perceptive (m/f)"
  pronunciation="Ty CHUY-ny / CHUY-na"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ·Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¶Ğ´Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ Ñ‡ÑƒĞ¹Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¹."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ£ Ñ‚ĞµĞ±Ğµ Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğµ ÑĞµÑ€Ñ†Ğµ"
  translation="You have a heart of gold"
  pronunciation="U TE-be zo-lo-TE SER-tse"
  example="A beautiful expression of admiration."
/>

### Intelligence and Talent

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ·ÑƒĞ¼Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¹/Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ·ÑƒĞ¼Ğ½Ğ°"
  translation="You are smart (m/f)"
  pronunciation="Ty ro-ZUM-ny / ro-ZUM-na"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ° Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ·ÑƒĞ¼Ğ½Ğ°!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¹/Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ°"
  translation="You are talented (m/f)"
  pronunciation="Ty ta-la-no-VY-ty / ta-la-no-VY-ta"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ½ĞµĞ¹Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ²Ñ–Ñ€Ğ½Ğ¾ Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¹!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ³ĞµĞ½Ñ–Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ¸Ğ¹/Ğ³ĞµĞ½Ñ–Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ°"
  translation="You are a genius (m/f)"
  pronunciation="Ty ge-ni-AL-ny / ge-ni-AL-na"
  example="Ğ¦Ñ Ñ–Ğ´ĞµÑ Ğ³ĞµĞ½Ñ–Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ°, ÑĞº Ñ– Ñ‚Ğ¸!"
/>

### Humor and Fun

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ ÑĞ¼Ñ–ÑˆĞ½Ğ¸Ğ¹/ÑĞ¼Ñ–ÑˆĞ½Ğ°"
  translation="You are funny (m/f)"
  pronunciation="Ty smish-NY / smish-NA"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ ÑĞ¼Ñ–ÑˆĞ½Ğ¸Ğ¹!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ— Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ Ğ²ĞµÑĞµĞ»Ğ¾"
  translation="It's fun being with you"
  pronunciation="Z to-BO-yu VE-se-lo"
  example="Ğ— Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ Ğ·Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¶Ğ´Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°Ğº Ğ²ĞµÑĞµĞ»Ğ¾!"
/>

<CultureTip title="Ukrainian Soul" flag="ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦">
Ukrainians deeply value sincerity in compliments. Superficial flattery is easily detected, but genuine admiration - especially about someone's character, soul, or inner qualities - is truly treasured and remembered.
</CultureTip>

## Romantic Compliments

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ - Ğ¼Ğ¾Ñ” Ñ‰Ğ°ÑÑ‚Ñ"
  translation="You are my happiness"
  pronunciation="Ty - mo-YE SHCHAS-tya"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ¸ - Ğ²ÑĞµ Ğ¼Ğ¾Ñ” Ñ‰Ğ°ÑÑ‚Ñ."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ¼ĞµĞ½Ğµ Ñ‰Ğ°ÑĞ»Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ¼/Ñ‰Ğ°ÑĞ»Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¾Ñ"
  translation="You make me happy (m/f speaker)"
  pronunciation="Ty RO-bysh me-NE shchas-LY-vym / shchas-LY-vo-yu"
  example="ĞšĞ¾Ğ¶ĞµĞ½ Ğ´ĞµĞ½ÑŒ Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¸Ñˆ Ğ¼ĞµĞ½Ğµ Ñ‰Ğ°ÑĞ»Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ¼."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ - Ğ½Ğ°Ğ¹ĞºÑ€Ğ°Ñ‰Ğµ, Ñ‰Ğ¾ Ñ‚Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¿Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¾ÑÑŒ Ñƒ Ğ¼Ğ¾Ñ”Ğ¼Ñƒ Ğ¶Ğ¸Ñ‚Ñ‚Ñ–"
  translation="You're the best thing that happened in my life"
  pronunciation="Ty - nay-KRA-shche, shcho tra-PY-los u mo-YE-mu zhyt-TI"
  example="The ultimate romantic compliment."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¯ Ğ³Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ´Ğ¶ÑƒÑÑ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ"
  translation="I'm proud of you"
  pronunciation="Ya gor-JU-sya to-BO-yu"
  example="Ğ¯ Ñ‚Ğ°Ğº Ğ³Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ´Ğ¶ÑƒÑÑ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="ĞŸĞ¾Ñ€ÑƒÑ‡ Ğ· Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ Ñ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ñ‡ÑƒĞ²Ğ°ÑÑÑ Ğ¾ÑĞ¾Ğ±Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ¼/Ğ¾ÑĞ¾Ğ±Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ¾Ñ"
  translation="I feel special when I'm with you (m/f)"
  pronunciation="PO-ruch z to-BO-yu ya po-chu-VA-yu-sya os-ob-LY-vym / os-ob-LY-vo-yu"
  example="Express how they make you feel."
/>

## Complimenting Actions and Efforts

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ³Ğ¾Ñ‚ÑƒÑ”Ñˆ Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ¶ĞµÑÑ‚Ğ²ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ğ¾"
  translation="You cook divinely"
  pronunciation="Ty go-TU-yesh bo-ZHEST-ven-no"
  example="Ğ¦Ñ ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ° Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ¶ĞµÑÑ‚Ğ²ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ğ°!"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ²ÑĞµ Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¸Ñˆ Ñ–Ğ´ĞµĞ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ¾"
  translation="You do everything perfectly"
  pronunciation="Ty vse RO-bysh i-de-AL-no"
  example="Admire their efforts."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="ĞœĞµĞ½Ñ– Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ°Ñ”Ñ‚ÑŒÑÑ, ÑĞº Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ñ†Ğµ Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¸Ñˆ"
  translation="I like how you do this"
  pronunciation="Me-NI po-DO-ba-yet-sya, yak ty tse RO-bysh"
  example="Acknowledge their unique way."
/>

## Poetic Comparisons

Ukrainians love poetic and lyrical expressions:

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ ĞºÑ€Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ²Ğ° ÑĞº Ñ‚Ñ€Ğ¾ÑĞ½Ğ´Ğ°"
  translation="You're beautiful like a rose"
  pronunciation="Ty kra-SY-va yak tro-YAN-da"
  example="Classic romantic comparison."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ ÑÑÑ”Ñˆ ÑĞº ÑĞ¾Ğ½Ñ†Ğµ"
  translation="You shine like the sun"
  pronunciation="Ty SYA-yesh yak SON-tse"
  example="You brighten everything."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Ğ¢Ğ¸ ÑĞº Ğ°Ğ½Ğ³ĞµĞ»"
  translation="You're like an angel"
  pronunciation="Ty yak AN-gel"
  example="Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ¼Ñ–Ğ¹ Ğ°Ğ½Ğ³ĞµĞ»!"
/>

<CultureTip title="Flowers and Compliments" flag="ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦">
In Ukrainian culture, flowers often accompany verbal compliments. Men traditionally bring flowers when meeting their partner. Remember: odd numbers of flowers are for happy occasions, while even numbers are reserved for funerals.
</CultureTip>

## Responding to Compliments

When your partner compliments you, here's how to respond:

| Ukrainian | Pronunciation | English |
|---------|---------------|---------|
| Ğ”ÑĞºÑƒÑ | DYA-ku-yu | Thank you |
| Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ‚ĞµĞ¶ | Ty tezh | You too |
| Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ¼ĞµĞ½Ñ– Ğ»ĞµÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ñˆ | Ty me-NI LES-tysh | You flatter me |
| ĞŸÑ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ´Ğ°? | PRAV-da | Really? |
| Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¹/Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ° | Ty ta-KY MY-ly / MY-la | You're so sweet |
| ĞœĞµĞ½Ñ– Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸Ñ”Ğ¼Ğ½Ğ¾ Ñ†Ğµ Ñ‡ÑƒÑ‚Ğ¸ | Me-NI pry-YEM-no tse CHU-ty | That's nice to hear |

## Daily Compliments to Use

Make it a habit to compliment your partner daily:

| Situation | Ukrainian | English |
|-----------|---------|---------|
| Morning | Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ñ‡ÑƒĞ´Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾ Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ»ÑĞ´Ğ°Ñ”Ñˆ | You look wonderful |
| After cooking | Ğ”ÑƒĞ¶Ğµ ÑĞ¼Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ½Ğ¾! | Very delicious! |
| Getting dressed | Ğ¢Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ– Ğ»Ğ¸Ñ‡Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ | It suits you |
| Working hard | Ğ¢Ğ¸ Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ´ĞµÑ†ÑŒ | Well done / You're great |
| Being supportive | Ğ”ÑĞºÑƒÑ, Ñ‰Ğ¾ Ñ‚Ğ¸ Ñ” | Thanks for being you |
| Before bed | ĞœĞµĞ½Ñ– Ğ¿Ğ¾Ñ‰Ğ°ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¾ Ğ· Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ | I'm lucky to have you |
